Mike,

If =
you only use your own tag libraries then you should have no problem
running=
 JSPs with mock objects, although there are quite a few interfaces
to imple=
ment.

We use a small set of custom tags extensively to a give us a look an=
d feel
on all our pages.  We don't seem to have found any performance probl=
ems.
My only advise here is that if you are using weblogic then it's best t=
o
manually remove references to beans from the request and response scope
a=
fter a page has been generated, or they won't be garbage collected.  But
th=
ink I am starting to go off-topic...

One approach that can be used is to i=
mplement the RequestDispatcher of your
mock Servlet container such that whe=
n you can intercept forwards and
includes.  This way you can assert that th=
e Servlet has added the correct
beans to the request so that the JSP can re=
nder the correct view.

     Paul Hodgetts wrote:

     > Peter Qi wrote:
  =
   >
     >  > I need to create some JUnit tests for a Servlet.  But becaus=
e the
     >  > doGet(HttpServletRequest, HttpServletResponse) and

> doPost(HttpServletRequest, HttpServletResponse) methods have no

rns,

 by

es anyone

=
     >
     > You can use HTTPUnit to run tests against the servlet.  The
 =
    > problem, however, as you point out, is that you only have
     > limi=
ted visibility into the servlet, since you can only check
     > the return=
ed HTTP response to the web client.  It's gets even
     > more fun when yo=
u're trying to test the behavior of session
     > time outs, security and =
log in checks, etc.
     >
     > What we've discussed doing is to make our=
 servlets (and JSPs
     > via tag libraries) very thin layers that take th=
e incoming
     > requests and just delegate to our presentation helper cla=
sses.
     > In many cases, we'll end up just passing the request and
     =
> session objects along, but we now have a point where we can
     > create=
 the request or session objects in particular states
     > (like expired s=
ession), so we can much more easily test the
     > interface's behavior, p=
lus we can use JUnit.
     >
     > This isn't a silver bullet or anything,=
 because there are
     > still cases where you want to test the actual ret=
urned HTML,
     > and sometimes HTTPUnit tests are the best way to do that=
.
     > But it seems like it will make our life a bit easier for some
    =
 > other classes of presentation layer testing.
     >
     > Anyone else t=
ry this?
